Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2008 10:20PM catbert4209 wrote: Dion:  My heart goes out to you!  If it is any help, many of the women on this board have been in the place you are now.  I have found a tremendous source of courage and hope from these wonderful ladies.  The chat room is another great place to "talk" about your fears. The important thing is to know you are not alone.  There are people who will listen, both on this board and in your life.  I found it really helped me to pull in my support system--my "walk-and-talk" buddies, the women in my choir, and my friends at work.  Don't be afraid to reach out and ask for help, even if it is just for someone to give you a shoulder to cry on.  Your fiance may not be able to do this--my husband actually got sick himself when he found out I had breast cancer. You are in my thoughts and prayers!  Take care, and let me know how you are doing! Cat

I'll be sending you warm, positive thoughts tomorrow! Let us know how you're doing and if there is anything we can do! Cat

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2008 12:44AM - edited Apr 7, 2008 12:44AM by catbert4209 Mary: I've had a surgical biopsy, two lumpectomies and a bilateral mastectomy, all within the last seven months.  Each time, I went in relaxed and woke up easily.  The only "problem" I encountered was that my mouth was very dry when I woke up, so I became the queen of the ice chips!  The best thing about waking up from the bilateral was that my first coherent thought was "no more breast cancer!"  All the best to you!  Let us know how you're doing! Cat

God bless you! Cat

Posts.Content: Dec 8, 2007 01:01AM catbert4209 wrote: Barb--Well the path results came back, and they show DCIS.  The margins are not good, and my oncologist, radio-oncologist and surgeon are all recommending mastectomy.  I am choosing to have  a bilateral done.  I'm not going for reconstruction immediately, but will "reward" myself with that after making sure I am cancer-free and losing that 15 pounds I keep promising myself  to lose! I am very much at peace with this decision, which tells me it is the right one. I also am very glad to be in Houston--the Medical Center, Baylor College of Medicine and MD Anderson are tremendous resources. Let  me know how you are doing! Cat
Posts.Title: Why am I not upset? Barbara1 Mary-Lou

Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2008 10:25PM catbert4209 wrote: Deidre:  Just one more piece of advice--get a copy of the path report!  Find out what is on that piece of paper!!  Your surgeon's admin can fax this to you or e-mail it to you, but it is very important that you know what is on that report. I cannot believe your doc would not spend more time with you on this.  It's too important to just walk in, spit out the news and then walk out without making sure all your questions are answered.  Unbelievable! Cat

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2008 06:47PM catbert4209 wrote: Otter: Your story sounds very familiar!!  I'm 55, too, and in August I was diagnosed with two areas of Stage 1 invasive ductal carcinoma in my left breast.  I initially wanted a mastectomy, but was told that "standard of care" was breast conservation followed by radiation.  I had a surgical breast biopsy in September which I thought would get all the tumor.  The margins were not good, however, and I had a lumpectomy in October.  I then had an MRI in November prior to starting radiation therapy which found that there was still residual disease in the breast and that there was a suspicious area on the right side.  I was ready then for a mastectomy, but my surgeon and oncologist both said they thought another lumpectomy (on both sides) would be sufficient.  That was done in December.  When the pathology came back from that surgery, the margins still showed DCIS still remaining in the left breast and possible DCIS in the right.   I have had enough!  I am scheduled for a bilateral mastectomy with immediate reconstruction with implants on January 30th.  I want the peace of mind that this disease is out of my body.   If I had it to do over again, I would probably have had the first lumpectomy and then opted for the mastectomy when they found the residual disease.  This is a very personal decision, and only you can know what you can and cannot tolerate.  Please stay in touch and let us know how you are!!  You can get a lot of support from this board and the marvelous women who frequent it! Cat

Posts.Content: Jun 16, 2008 10:47PM catbert4209 wrote: All I've ever given them is my number from my insurance card.  There is nothing in the law that states you have to give your Social Security # out to doctors or hospitals.  If you are concerned about identity theft, you can request a copy of your credit report from any of the credit agencies, and they are required to provide you with one.  You can do this annually.  There are credit reporting agencies that operate through the banks now--I have a monthly report coming to me to let me know if there is any unauthorized activity on my credit report.  With all the information we have had to give out, this is one step that provides me with a little sense of security! Sue, the reason I took my wedding ring off and left it at home had nothing to do with "explosions" in the OR.  I wanted to be sure it was secure some place when I was going to be non-compus-mentus!  I think that is the real reason they ask you to leave jewelry at home--the hospital does not want to be responsible for making sure the jewelry does not get stolen. Cat
Posts.Title: Do you give or not give your SS#? PineHouse ICanDoThis

Posts.Title: Drain tube broke!!! RJ62 RJ62

Posts.Content: Dec 6, 2007 11:30PM catbert4209 wrote: Barb: Keep laughing!  Your first post resonated with me because I had a similar reaction.  I think my doctor was expecting me to be in hysterics, and all I could think and say was "It is what it is--now what do we do about it."   I was diagnosed in September, had the lumpectomy/lymph node surgery in October, had an MRI in November, and just completed another lumpectomy to get out the residual stuff found by the MRI!  I'm waiting on the pathology report to find out whether I'm heading to radiation or chemotherapy.  I, too, am in my 50's (just turned 55) and in menopause. Laughing is helping.  So is singing.  I rejoined my choir at church, and have found great joy in music again.  I have also been overwhelmed by the caring of friends there--my choir director asked if he could connect me with "some" of the women in the choir who had gone through what we are going through, and I have found myself surrounded with support.  I think if God has closed a door of my life (I will probably quit working), he has opened a window through these wonderful women. This chat room is another source of support.  I am thinking of you and Cath and wish both of you strength and healing! Cat
Posts.Title: Why am I not upset? Barbara1 Mary-Lou

Posts.Content: Dec 8, 2007 06:19AM catbert4209 wrote: Twinkly and all--Thank you for this posting!  I just received my path results from my third attempt at breast conservation, and they show DCIS throughout my breast.  I'm opting for the bilateral because the second breast has a suspicious, "probably benigh" area, and "probably" just doesn't sound good enough to me anymore!  My surgery is scheduled for Dec. 18th. I think I'm going to use the time after the surgery to recover, lose weight and then reward myself with reconstruction after the oncologist says I'm clear of this disease! All the best to everyone!  Hope your surgeries and recoveries go well!  Keep in touch!   Cat
